All matter is composed of atoms, which are made up of protons, neutrons, and electrons. Protons and neutrons reside in the nucleus and determine the identity and properties of an element. Electrons orbit the nucleus and determine the chemical properties of an element. The interaction between protons, neutrons, and electrons determines the unique properties of each element and how they combine to form compounds and molecules.

The number of protons in an atom determines its chemical properties, such as its identity and reactivity, through the element's unique atomic number, while the number of neutrons affects the atom's overall mass through its mass number, but not its chemical properties.
